data.text: A Female Bike Saddle to Avoid Hip Pain when Long-Distance Cycle Touring

My dearest bikers & travellers, what bike seat you have? Female here üòÅ I noticed some hips issues lately with my wide, soft padded seat... it gave me thousands of kilometers of behind - pain free rides, but I notice long term it's not a good solution. Any advice? Thank you!
Brooks B-17. Long break in but worth it. They have slightly shorter in length saddles for females too.

data.text: Basically, there are about 5 different postures that put very different pressures on your saddle. You need to ensure that you are using the right one. A B17 puts a lot of pressure on the perinieum if you are too upright, but that's more of a male concern. https://www.cyclingabout.com/saddle-comfort-for-cyclists-the-best-bicycle-touring-seats/
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: You're probably in the 3-4 range depending on the day/ hour etc.
data.author: Ken Staley

data.text: my seat is nr. 5, wide and soft... Yes, a mix between 3, 4 and 5, depending on the road...
data.author: Tamara Gkikas

data.text: Soft is a trap, it involves a lot more tissue and nerves. The leather saddles work on a hammock principle and move with you being firm on the sit bones but complient. Once you break one in to you you'll never waste any more money on the latest, greatest, lesser saddles. The b17s come in a wide array of configurations and the Gille Berthoude as well but they can be built from the ground up. They're expensive but it's a 4 -10 proposition. The serviceable ones are a lifetime purchase. All of the leather saddles are comparable and you won't go wrong. Get fitted with bottom measurements and make your decision from an educated position.
data.author: Ken Staley

data.text: Yes to the Brooks. They are the best for long rides as they conform to your shape in time.
data.author: Ed Hall

data.text: Specialized have a special program for you to find the most adapted sadle to.your hips. You must go to a Specialized bike shop, you sit down on molding seat that mesures your hips bones width , then the program proposes several sadle that might fir you, you can try them , then buy the one you prefer!
data.author: Fend La Buche

data.text: I went years suffering with saddle sores and other discomfort before finally doing a professional bike fit. NOT all bike fits are the same though. In this one, he measured by sit bones and pressure points as I was riding. Then made a recommendation of a saddle I would not have picked on my own. I've been riding it with fully loaded packs for the past couple of weeks and it is AMAZING. Everyone is configured differently so taking a recommendation for a specific saddle may be a waste of money if it doesn't fit you. GOOD LUCK!
data.author: Bliss Sawyer

data.text: yes, that is a really good advice! I did consider a professional bike fitting, there is one exactly as you describe it. I had no issues with saddle sores ever in my life with the seat I have (Acor Gel padded one), but after 30 years of abuse of my hips üòÖ, I feel it's time to change the seat to something more professional....and do the bike fitting, absolutely!
data.author: Tamara Gkikas

data.text: I was also suprised because he gave me a shorter stem and longer post. Felt strange to begin with but I can definitely see the difference
data.author: Bliss Sawyer

data.text: yes, I do believe that might be a game changer. Also noticed not being the same in my saddle after giving birth...for sure I will need adjustments! Thanks for pointing this out! ü§ó
data.author: Tamara Gkikas

data.text: I've ridden many a saddle and they all have their + and -. Padded are a two edge sword, comfy at first but self defeating. I found, in the never- ending quest for a happy butt, a leather Selle- Anatomica for a buck and thought, "What the hell..." although I was happy with my specialized when I mounted it I remembered the difference between on the saddle and in the saddle. It was heaven. Beat myself up one day and the next jump on the saddle with no reservations. Brooks no longer makes the saddle I wanted so I got an upgrade with Gille Berthoude. It's still being broken in but I can always throw the Selle back on for awhile. Leather saddles are kind of like shoes, it's it the shoe breaking in or the foot? But it's all well worth it. The comfort of a leather saddle you've broken in is unsurpassed.
data.author: Ken Staley

data.text: Price IS an issue. $200 for a leather saddle or $100 a piece for four or five plastic padded ones.
data.author: Ken Staley

data.text: I love a charge spoon, seems to get great reviews for most folk I have spoken too. https://sdjsports.com/products/charge-spoon-classic-bike-saddle

data.text: I transfered my charge spoon to 3 consecutive bikes and when the last bike got stolen I ordered a new one for my current bike. Great saddle and not expensive

data.text: The first thing you should do is go to a bike shop and get measured for a saddle. Its a 2 minute job. Brooks do make great saddles but they do not suit everyone and they are expensive. I have 2 of them. There are many cheaper saddles which are not made of leather and are just as good as Brooks.

data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: Advice from a long-time bicycle mechanic and fitter: test as many saddles as you can. Some shops offer test ride programs for a nominal fee, some of your friends may have saddles they can loan you to try. Personally, I really like the saddles from Selle Anatomica even though I was a Brooks fanboy for many years. Your ischial tuberosities (sitz bones) are going to be different from other peoples‚Äô, as well as the rest of your anatomy. What is comfortable to others will be uncomfortable to you. Unfortunately, finding your dream saddle is a long, personal process that will require experimentation, pain, and suffering. Godspeed and good luck.
